Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Social Lives of HIV Prevention Drugs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Since its arrival to the market, Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) has transformed the field of HIV prevention. A once a day pill composed of conventional antiretrovirals repurposed for preventative use, research has proven PrEP to be highly effective in reducing individual risk of HIV infection. While studies have demonstrated PrEPâ€™s therapeutic efficacy, the social effects of this therapeutic revolution across different groups and populations remains understudied. The research supported by this award uses ethnographic methods to investigate how different populations and individuals use PrEP, asking how the use of this drug effects individual practices, as well as perceptions of risk. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project will enhance scientific understandings of the social effects of HIV prevention strategies and therapies. <br/><br/>The research will take place over 16 months in a context where PrEP has been made widely available through the production and distribution of a state manufactured generic. The researcher will work across four different community settings: a HIV policy institute, a private clinic, a community organization, and a selection of commercial and event venues that are significant to the local economy. Data will be collected through participant observation; interviews with health policy makers, doctors, community organizers, PrEP users, and other stakeholders; and focus groups and life histories of PrEP users from different population groups. Findings from this research will produce multi-perspective data needed by policy makers, public health practitioners, and social scientists to understand the factors that condition both access to and the broader experiences of these novel forms of therapy.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in 18 months of fieldwork that was conducted primarily in Bangkok, Thailand from June 2021 thru December 2022. The goal of this fieldwork was to ethnographically document the therapeutic revolution surrounding PrEP, an oral prophylactic used to lower risk of HIV infection, exploring not only how the arrival of this new medical technology was changing community-based healthcare practice and service delivery, but also how it was affecting understandings of health, behavior, and identity among PrEP users themselves. Funding for this project supported recurrent interviews with PrEP users, as well as the collection of life histories and interviews with clinicians and staff from across a half a dozen relevant clinics and community-based care organizations.

Charting the social life of this drug, research from this fieldwork documents the myriad ways in which the effects of PrEP exceed its therapeutic bounds, impacting not only various individuals and communities' understandings of their health and sexual behaviors, but also provoking new forms of self-identity, as well as new political understandings around the relationship between pleasure, care, intimacy, work, and community. Through an anthropological analysis of how this drug is being used across clinical and non-clinical settings in the fashioning of new subjectivities and the reconfiguring of therapeutic relations, the research contributes to theory in both medical anthropology and science and technology studies (STS) that argues for social approaches to pharmaceuticals that see effect not as predetermined, but as configured through relations. By documenting the social lives of this HIV prevention drug, the research argues for an approach to drugs that is not limited to the substance itself, but that also accounts for the economic, social, political, and symbolic dimensions at play within any given context.  Furthermore, through the study's empirical engagement with the work of public health practitioners, the research also contributes to broader understandings of contemporary movements to manage the spread of HIV.
